div.l: And to hym selfe he made grete wo
Allas quod he this is a wicked Iape
Nowe may I sey that I is but an ape
Yet hath my felowe somewhate for his harm
He hath the Millers doughter in his arm
He auntrid and his nedes sped
And I lye as a draf sack in my bed
And when this Iape is told anothir day
I shalbe holde a daff a cokeney
I wille aryse and auntre me be my feith
Vnhardy vnsely thus mēn seith
And vp he ros and softly he went
Vnto the cradille and in his arm hit hent
And bare it softe vnto his beddis fete
Sone aftir the wiff hir rotynge lete
And gan a wake and went hir out to pisse
And cam ayen and gan hir cradil mysse
And groped here and there but she fond none
Allas quod she I had almost mys gone
I had almost gone to the clerkes bed
Do wey benedicite than had I foule sped
And forth she goth tille she the cradil fond
She gropoth alwey ferthir wᵗith hir honde
And fonde the bed and thought not but good
Be cause that the Cradil be it stod
And nyst never where she was for it was derke
But faire and welle she crepeth vnto the clerke
And lieth fulle stille ⁊and wold haue caught a slepe
Wᵗithyn a while this Iohn vp leep
And on this good wiff he lieth on sore
So mery a fitt had not she fulle yore
He pricketh harde and sore as he were mad
This ioly lyff haue thys two clerkes lad
